message.content: This question requires reasoning based on basic knowledge of the relationship between plants, soil, and animals. When trees grow in soil rich with a certain vitamin, they absorb that vitamin through their roots and incorporate it into their tissues. As a result, animals that consume parts of the trees, such as squirrels, would also have that vitamin in their system. Option (A) is incorrect because vitamins do not evaporate. Option (B) is also incorrect because once the vitamin is absorbed by the trees, it is not likely to leak back into the ground. Option (C) is unsupported and untruthful.

This question tests our understanding of nutrient uptake in plants and the transfer of nutrients through the food chain. If the trees in an area are growing in soil rich with a certain vitamin, they will absorb and accumulate that vitamin in their tissues. As a result, the squirrels that feed on the trees or their fruits will also obtain that vitamin, as it is transferred through the food chain. Option (A) is incorrect because vitamins do not evaporate. Option (B) is also incorrect because if the soil is rich in the vitamin, it is unlikely to leak back into the ground. Option (C) is incorrect because there is no evidence to suggest that trees would mutate and die in response to a vitamin-rich soil.
